info.game_comments:
Ken Jennings game 65.  Ken breaks Kevin Olmstead's record for biggest amount of money won on a television game show.
U.S. presidential election coverage bumped this game's airing by one day.  Affiliates with no election coverage aired the "4,000th Episode" special (#4088) on 2004-11-02.

(1, 1).clue: Served hot or cold, this "European" style of potato salad is made with vinegar & bacon

(2, 1).clue: A regular rocket scientist, U.S. Representative Rush Holt of this "Garden State" was a nuclear physicist

(3, 1).clue: This Braves slugger hit 375 of his 755 career home runs in the 1960s

(4, 1).clue: The Sanskrit juel, "to shine", was transmuted into this 4-letter element by Anglo-Saxons

(5, 1).clue: This large Swiss city is on the western end of Lake Geneva

(6, 1).clue: To the Germans & Vietnamese, these say wau wau when chasing a postman or a cat

(1, 2).clue: Spaghetti a la this has a sauce made with eggs, cream, Parmesan cheese & Italian bacon

(2, 2).clue: Congressman Tom Osborne used to coach a little football at this Big 12 school, going 255-49-3

(3, 2).clue: On May 8, 1968 this "fishy" Oakland A's pitcher threw the only A.L. perfect game of the 1960s

(4, 2).clue: With 1 as its atomic number, this gas heads up the periodic table

(5, 2).clue: Surely you know this was the first name of author Evelyn Waugh's first wife

(6, 2).clue: It will wake you up with kokekokko in Japan  & kykeliky in Norway

(1, 3).clue: Oui!  This thick, round cut of lean beef tenderloin is popularly served with a bacon strip wrap around it

(2, 3).clue: Don't "procrastinate"; tell us the name of this house majority leader & ex-exterminator from Houston

(3, 3).clue: In 1968 this Cincinnati Reds player became the first catcher ever named Rookie of the Year

(4, 3).clue: In the electronics industry, this element symbolized Si, is made into N- & P-types of semiconductors

(5, 3).clue: In 2004 publisher David Carey announced that more Californians than New Yorkers subscribed to this magazine

(6, 3).clue: Albanian ones say hunk hunk; maybe it's the smell that makes French ones say groin groin while truffle hunting

(1, 4).clue: Named for a French region, it's a brunch dish of eggs, crumbled bacon & often Swiss cheese in a pastry shell

(2, 4).clue: Congressman Don Young of this state can list "Fort Yukon Riverboat Captain" on his resume

(3, 4).clue: This St. Louis Cardinals pitcher was named MVP of the 1964 & 1967 World Series

(4, 4).clue: Its symbol Hg comes from the Latin hydrargyrum, "watery silver"

(5, 4).clue: (Hi, I'm Ari Fleischer.)  Now named for James Brady, this room in the White House is where the briefing of the press takes place

(6, 4).clue: In Argentina they berp; Swedish ones kvack while hopping

(1, 5).clue: Wrap bacon around a water chestnut & a piece of chicken liver  & you've got this Asian-style appetizer

(2, 5).clue: Senator Lincoln Chafee of this New England state spent 7 years as a blacksmith at racetracks in the U.S. & Canada

(3, 5).clue: In 1967 this Red Sox outfielder became the last Major Leaguer to win hitting's Triple Crown

(4, 5).clue: Oxides of this silver-white metallic element are used in pigments to give some ceramics a vivid blue color

(5, 5).clue: In 2004 Whistling Straits in Wisconsin hosted this PGA championship

(6, 5).clue: They say piv while stealing havarti & squitt squitt if they get into the provolone

(1, 1).clue: Bring home this 1984 movie & you'll see Kevin kick off his Sunday shoes & dance up a storm

(2, 1).clue: Most of these in the Northern Hemisphere have broken off from Greenland

(5, 1).clue: "The Count of Monte Cristo" & "The Black Tulip" are a pere of his historical romances

(6, 1).clue: From the Greek for "to see", it's a wide & unobstructed view of an extensive area in all directions

(1, 2).clue: Recent film in which Kevin played a detective & childhood pal of grieving father Sean Penn

(2, 2).clue: 1978's SEASAT, a companion to LANDSAT, was the first one of these dedicated to oceanography

(3, 2).clue: He's the author of 1987's "The Art of the Deal"

(4, 2).clue: A plaque honoring the men who died building Hoover Dam reads, "They died to make" this type of area "bloom"

(5, 2).clue: In 1973 the KGB confiscated a manuscript of this massive work & Solzhenitsyn soon published it in France

(6, 2).clue: A flag, a pedestal or a song often used in repertories

(1, 3).clue: See Kevin in his film debut as a pledge for the rival Omega House in this comedy classic

(2, 3).clue: Sea otters & garibaldies are inhabitants of these "forests"

(3, 3).clue: His 1940 "Portrait of the Artist as a Young Dog" is semi-autobiographical

(4, 3).clue: A plaque at the Annapolis Docks honoring the arrival of this "Roots" slave was stolen within days of its dedication

(5, 3).clue: Detective Cordelia Gray debuted in this Englishwoman's "An Unsuitable Job for a Woman"

(6, 3).clue: The scientific name of this whale is Megaptera novaeangliae, or "Big-winged New Englander"

(1, 4).clue: Kevin's role in this movie seen here may have left him feeling a bit empty

(2, 4).clue: This word means a school of fish or a shallow spot in the sea

(3, 4).clue: He lost to Rutherford B. Hayes by one electoral vote

(4, 4).clue: A plaque in the Louisiana state capitol marks the site of this violent event of Sept. 8, 1935

(5, 4).clue: If you can't come up with this Japanese title of Tayama Katai's novel translated as "The Quilt", sleep on it

(6, 4).clue: It's the death or decay of body tissue due to injury or failure of the blood supply

(1, 5).clue: Kevin & Elizabeth Perkins share a little romance as well as opposing viewpoints in this 1991 film

(2, 5).clue: The ocean crust sits or floats on the Earth's mantle & is composed mainly of this igneous rock

(3, 5).clue: Nat Turner led a slave revolt in the U.S. in 1831; he led a peasant revolt in England in 1381

(4, 5).clue: This American Nobel Laureate is seen here with a plaque at the site of his discovery of plutonium

(5, 5).clue: You can go back to medieval Norway by reading Sigrid Undset's novel about this woman & her father Lavrans

(6, 5).clue: The military term for weapons & ammunition, it can also describe the tools used to make them

(0, 0).clue: This king was the great-grandfather of France's King Louis XV
